caseTitle: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW THE LATE MR. JUSTICE AKUFO-ADDO [1980] VOL
summary: This document is a memorial tribute published in the Review of Ghana Law (1980) honoring the late Mr. Justice Edward Akufo-Addo, M.O.V., Hon. LL.D. (Oxon.), former Chief Justice and President of Ghana, who passed away on 17 July 1979. The tribute, delivered at a solemn ceremony on 5 May 1980, highlights his distinguished career as a lawyer, judge, statesman, and founding member of the United Gold Coast Convention. Akufo-Addo was called to the Bar in 1940 and rose to the Supreme Court in 1962, bypassing the High Court, a historic appointment. He served as Chief Justice from 1966 to 1970 and later as President of the Second Republic from 1970 until the 1972 coup. He was instrumental in chairing the 1967 Constitutional Commission and drafting the 1969 Constitution, which granted full autonomy to the judiciaryâ€”a legacy preserved in later constitutions. Known for his eloquence, moral integrity, and firm judicial demeanor, he was respected and sometimes feared on the bench. The tribute underscores his contributions to law, governance, and national development, and expresses deep national loss at his passing.
rationaleHighlights: Recognition of Akufo-Addo's role in establishing judicial autonomy via the 1969 Constitution
Emphasis on moral integrity and disciplined legal life
Praise for scholarly and well-reasoned judicial judgments
Acknowledgment of political challenges affecting judicial appointments
Tribute to Akufo-Addo's contribution to constitutional development in Ghana
confidenceNotes: The document is a commemorative tribute rather than a judicial decision, so standard legal case elements like verdict and winning side are not applicable. Information is derived from a formal memorial publication by the Review of Ghana Law.
